author: {'steamid': '76561198041856540', 'num_games_owned': 919, 'num_reviews': 275, 'playtime_forever': 89, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 89, 'last_played': 1679800378}
review:
A fairly polished minesweeper game, it gives what it says on the tin, a seemingly endless queue of minesweeper boards.

Overall it feels like this game was made for the pro / competitive scene - as a casual player I found its UI, scoring and item systems overly strict to the degree that borders on player-hostile. Eg. you have a few seconds to grab items, and the game happily lets you waste items without explaining what they do.

I think the experience's most significant downside comes from the weakness of the minesweeper genre itself - namely that at a large proportion of games you are reduced to guessing, as there is no logical step forward. I think it's part of the reason why I prefer picross to minesweeper.

Still leaning towards a recommended rating, as Fine Sweeper does what it sets out to do, and at a competent quality.

review:
[h1]🎮 [u]Fine Sweeper[/u] 🎮 [/h1] 

Die bisher einzige Veröffentlichung von [url=https://store.steampowered.com/search/?developer=Pixel%20Prophecy]Pixel Prophecy[/url] auf Steam, hüllt den Klassiker Mine Sweeper in ein neues Gewandt und bietet uns Dank ein paar Herausforderungen, die es zu erfüllen gilt um alle Errungenschaften zu erhalten, auch einen gewissen wettkampforientierten Modus. Das Spielprinzip selbst blieb gleich: Heißt man klickt auf einem Feld mit lauter versteckten Bomben herum und markiert diese anhand dessen was die freigeschalteten Zahlen einem sagen. Je weiter man kommt, desto komplizierter die Level - 50 an der Zahl. Doch in dieser Version hat man mit Herzen (=Leben) und anderen Gimmicks die Möglichkeit nicht beim ersten Fehltritt Game Over zu sein. Es ist diesbezüglich Benutzer freundlicher. Grafisch ist das Ganze eine 2D-Oberfläche und akustisch nichts Weltbewegendes.
 
[b]Fazit[/b] 

Wer den Klassiker mochte, findet hier eine neue Herausforderung die optisch verbessert wurde. Der Schwierigkeitsgrad steigt kontinuierlich und durch die Herausforderungen gibt es auch eine Art Wettbewerb. Insofern sind die 2,99 Euro ganz gut investiert, auch wenn man das Rad nicht neu erfindet. Circa 17 Stunden Spielzeit sprechen denke ich für sich!

review:
Minesweeper + Quality of Life Improvements = Fine Sweeper
---

If it wasn't obvious enough from the store page, Fine Sweeper could easily be called a clone of Minesweeper. But it's not quite a clone, it's a much improved variant that offers a greater sense of progression, less random failures (that aren't your fault) and numerous other (minor) improvements that total up to a much better game than the one it's cloned from.

If you already know what Minesweeper is and want a better version of it, this is a no brainer. It's a cheap and pleasant way to kill some time and play with brain teasing puzzles.

If you aren't familiar with Minesweeper, it's a classic game that used to be included with early versions of Windows operating systems to give people a fun way to practice their mouse clicking skills (yes, prior to a mouse being a ubiquitous and common tool, people honestly didn't know how to use the thing well). These days (for whatever reason) it's no longer included by default with Windows 10, but can be found for free through various sources.

Sometimes you just want a simple relaxing series of puzzles to chip away the hours.
---

EDIT: I've been playing this game a lot more lately. I guess I just have a thing for simple puzzles and minesweeper was something of an addiction 30 years ago, so here we are all over again. If I have one issue with this game it's the repetitive music. Of course, most of you already know how easy it is to solve that: Just turn down the music (not the sound effects) and listen to your own music.

Did you enjoy minesweeper?  This game is a minesweeper variant with extra features. You get lives, there’s score keeping and of course Achievements. As a fan of minesweeper I really enjoyed the game. 

Gameplay -  9

This is a pretty niche type of game. If you don’t like minesweeper you probably won’t care for this game. If you have never played the game the basic idea is that you are sweeping for mines.  You pick a square and if it’s not a mine. Good job. If it is you blow up. Now if it’s not a bomb it will either be a blank space or a space with a number in it.  If it’s blank. Move on to another space. The number tells you how many mines are in the 8 squares around that 1 square.  From there it’s just using logic to figure out where the mines are located. 

Story -  N/A



Graphics -  8

Pretty decent, easy to read and there is no confusion.  Not much else to say. 


Controls - MouseKeyboard -10

You left click to uncover a single square, right click to mark mines. Left and right click on a number, that already has associated mines marked,  and it’ll clear out all the area it can around. 
That’s pretty much it, you can also mark ?’s but I take off that feature in options. 

Repeatability - 8

It’s mine sweeper, you’re going to be playing the levels over and over.  There’s an achievement to get to level 7 in less than 1 minute. Not impossible, but difficult enough that you’ll be playing the first 6 levels over and over a few times. 



Music - ???

It’s there? Usually while gaming I listen to my own music, unless it’s a sound based game. 

Multiplayer - N/A 

Pretty sure there is not multiplayer, but there are online leaderboards.


Initial Thoughts: 

Oh a minesweeper type game. I haven’t played that game since I was a kid. Interesting you can earn extra lives and such.   


Soma Says: 

Normally I like to put in a good 10 or so hours into a game before reviewing it.  However, this game is an easy exception. I’ve put 100’s if not 1000’s into the original minesweeper.  I live an exciting life as you can tell. 

The addition of extra lives is a good one, it’s frustrating to hit a mine because you made a stupid mistake and have to start all over. This is just a more forgiving version of minesweeper. 

If you enjoyed minesweeper you might want to pick this up.  If you like sudoku puzzles or any type of logic puzzles this is a game you will most likely enjoy.  Also it’s 3 bucks.  Not exactly breaking the bank here.

review:
[h1][b]Fine Sweeper - Better Than The Original[/b][/h1]

I have to be honest, I hated the original game since it wasn't a puzzle game, it was a guessing game disguised as a puzzle game. You would get to points in the original where you just can't know what the right answer is and had to guess which more often than not would result in you blowing yourself up and starting over. Happily I can say that this version of Minesweeper is improved a lot from it's original 1989 counter-part. 

[h1]Story[/h1]
Pffffahaha, yeah right...

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
The gameplay of Minesweeper is where it really shines. As much as you can play many other copies of Minesweeper for free on the internet, this paid for version on steam introduces a few new features that really help the game elevate itself from it's thousands of copycats.

The way to win at this game is to empty out a grid where mines have been placed randomly around that grid. You click on one of these squares and it reveals an area with a number. These number indicate how many mines are in the surrounding area around that number. If a number is surrounded by 8 other squares and the number is 3 that means that 3 out of those 8 squares have bombs in them. By revealing more areas you gain more information that you can use to dig out the mines safely.

[b]*Useful Features*[/b]
I like to put special emphasis on these new features since they are the only reason why I am not telling you to just play Minesweeper for free on the internet instead of paying 3€ for this steam version.

[b]Multiple lives[/b]
The inclusion of multiple lives makes it so that even if you do get to a point where you just have to guess it's not as devastating to get it wrong since you just lose one of multiple lives and can carry on instantly afterwards compared to the older ones that didn't allow you to make a single mistake. This feature fixed the biggest standing issue I had with the game.

[b]Collateral Damage[/b]
Something I really enjoy is that if you do get so unfortunate to click on a mine and it blows up, when it explodes it also destroys the surrounding squares except for other mines meaning it can reveal other mines for you if you mess up. I enjoy this but also am a bit conflicted since it kind of feels like you are being rewarded for being wrong by being shown where other mines are. I do think however that this is something that can be disabled/enable in the options menu so it's not a problem, but I still think this feature is nice for someone that might be struggling with a certain level, and speaking of levels.

[b]Levels[/b]
The first Minesweeper game I have played that actually have levels and a rise in difficulty. It works really great because it keeps the player engaged and is a great way to have levels that are better tailored towards a particular players skill level. This is a huge improvement from the other games that only have "Beginner, Intermediate and Expert". This allows for a much bigger ranger of maps and difficulties to suit other players.

[b]Powers[/b]
While clearing out a grid you can stumble upon hearts on the field, if you have made a mistake earlier in the game you can left click on the heart and it fills out one of your heart containers, alternatively if you right click on it it gets added to a meter at the bottom left corner that after you have gathered enough hearts can be used for powers that help clear the grid a bit easier. The more hearts you invest in the meter the better the power will be when you use it which I found myself ignoring since I would rather just get the health but if your health is full it might be a good investment in the long run!

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
This game is great! I finally enjoy Minesweeper as a puzzle game and it feels really rewarding when you complete a level! This version has fixed long standing issues with the games and for that alone I think it is finally worth playing and even paying the little amount it asks for! I recommend!

review:
マインスイパーを製品にして出してみました的な作品。
いろいろ考えてあるとは思うけど購入してまでプレイする内容かと思えば微妙..

救済ありで失敗しても即ゲームオーバーではありません。

まあどっかのバンドルに入っていれば試してもいいが購入をすすめる作品ではないですね。
PC標準やフリーで探せばいいかと思います。

今回難しかった実績..まあ簡単にする方法や効率を上げる方法を紹介しておきます。
後はそれほどでもなかった記憶..

Need 4 Sweep
一気にクリアせず、クリア毎に中断再開で
時間はなぜか増えてなかったのでこれで達成。

Lapse FrenzyとThe Fine Sweeper
こっちは動画あがってるのでそれを参照した方がいいかな。
50レベルクリアで7つぐらいライフのため込できるようになると思われます。
その状態でカスタムゲームで6x6、爆弾34個を作成します。
3×3で4つに分けて考えて各真ん中をクリック
最初は必ず成功するのでそれが7なら
空けた上下をクリックすればどちらかでクリアできます。
8なら3×3の3つの真ん中を押していけばどこかでクリアできます。
この時クリアしたとき全部に旗が立ちます。
これがThe Fine Sweeperにカウントされます。
Lapse Frenzyは爆弾を5000個踏むしかないのでこれをやってまず数を稼ぎます。
The Fine Sweeperが達成されれば半分は超えると思われるので
あとはひたすら爆弾を踏む作業実施...本格的にやり始めて1日で一応達成できました。
面倒ですけどね..

review:
扫雷始终是规则单纯，又容易成瘾游戏的典范，玩法上这么多年了也不会改出什么花来，最主要是改动就是增加了多条命。
多条命是个很友好的设定，在遇到手气差猜错、手癌点错、懒得算瞎猜的时候不至于立刻死，但是这个红心的 UI 设计也实在有点烦人，完全遮挡视线，影响思考的流畅度。
另外 campaign 模式不插旗好像有挺大分数加成的，可以尽量不插旗，到实在觉得眼花了的关再插；时间的话，好像沙漏漏完了不会死，就是没时间加分，理论上可以不关键地慢慢玩。
然而这个游戏容易长时间在屏幕前长时间静坐，引起腰酸背痛，我自制力太差还是趁早卸载了。

review:

Additional Tags: Delete Local Content & Remove from LIbrary

TLDR: Minesweeper was free on windows and we all felt the need to get real games rather than the windows supplied ones due to their low fun factor.

The game can easily be resized with the HUD buttons and while it remains simple, there are small animations, FX for bombs going off and the health system was a really neat little touch as well as a smal campaign mode to supplement the custom board option.

Conclusion: If you are okay to go grid based, Hexcells remains servicable. However for the purists who want that classic minesweeper feel, this is an excellent direct step up which sticks to the core presentation and formula that made the original great. I suspect there are actually few people who would play this on a regular enough basis or have enough of an interest to obtain it outside of bundle purchases and in my case I see it best to archive it in hidden library.

"Se questa fosse qui allora  ce ne potrebbe sta solo una a questo di qua, questo da 3 ne avrebbe tutte de sopra. Fine Sweeper è un gioco gustoso che regala molte emozioni ed è utile a chi deve affrontare l'esame di Analisi 2 in Ingegneria. Per pochi euro potrete raggiungere, con solo due ore giornaliere di allenamento su questo gioco, lo stesso QI di Stiven Okking che dall'alto del cielo vi proteggerà e vi regalerà sane emozioni al gusto di fragola.

Il gioco fila liscio il frame rate stabile sui 60 fps (ricordiamo che l'occhio umano non vede oltre) ci regala la fluidità nelle animazioni fatte da 2 frame che andranno smooth anche sui calcolatori più deboli grazie al grande lavoro di ottimizzazione fatto dagli sviluppatori.

Questo T I T O L O è di una vastità e profondità di gameplay talmente alta e deep che le menti più geniali troveranno comunque divertimento nell'affrontare la sfida principale del gioco. Peccato l'assenza di modalità aggiuntive e di una modalità multi player.

In sintesi, tornando a noi, vi sconsiglio di comprarlo perché si potrebbe rivelare più pericoloso del crocodile.

review:
По какой то мне неводомой причине у игры много положительных плюсов. Я бы понял это если бы у многих кто писал обзор было бы наиграно по пару часов, но это не так.

Это классический сапёр но просто в другой цветовой схеме  (за 15 часов не видел всех сочетаний что на скриншотах). 

Из  приятного - можно собирать сердечки, одно сердечка равно одной жизи, либо можно собрать N-ое количество сердчек и получить никчемный бонус в виде подрыва бомб вокруг точки или целого ряда. Учитывая что для этого понадобится уйма сердечек, на уровне 50 их собирание для получения бонуса резко теряется.

Теперь о главно НЕДОСТАТКИ игры.
В классическом варианте игры на сложности эксперт игралось бодро и без проблем. В этой игре решили пойти дальше, поле ~того же размера но с каждым уровнем приростает количество бомб, вплоть до безумных цифр. В итоге бомб на поле так много что выиграть можно только благодоря везению. Это огромный НЕДОСТАТОК, т.к. пройти можно тупо благодаря счастливому обстоятельству. Вообщем не могу рекомендовать, современная версия в виндовс магазине будет получше.

[*]Right Click: Using a right-click on a square allows you to uncover adjacent squares when you've isloated a solution.  This aids in removing some "human error" scenarios once the player has fixed a solution for a square.

[b][u]Cons:[/u][/b]
[list]
[*]Achievements: Some of the achievements are luck based, but you can still get them by grinding away enough.
[*]Colors: At times, the game picks some colors that don't contrast well.  However, you can resolve this by completing the board, or just restarting your progress.
[/list]

Overall, I high recommend this game if you liked the original.  It is so much improved over the original version that came bundled with Windows.

review:
[h1] [b]KLASİK BULMACA OYUNU[/b] [/h1]

Windows'un 20 yıldan uzun süredir bir parçası olan klasik bulmaca oyunu.  Microsoft, Windows 3.1'e eklediğinde oyun ünlü oldu, ancak kökenleri daha eskidir.

[url=http://www.minesweeper.info/] Taihçesi, strateji ve ipuçlarını, dünya çapında turnuvaları, Dünya rekorlarını ve daha fazlasını öğrene bilirsiniz. [/url]  

Ayarlanabilir zorluk, klasik Minesweeper oyunu ve yepyeni oyun moduyla Fine Sweeper her zamankinden daha iyi.
Türkçeye çevirilerinden dolayı Cem Filiz'e teşekkür ederim.

[h1] Oyun Mantığı: [/h1]  Mayın Tarlası, görünüşte basit bir hafıza ve mantık oyunudur. Mayın Tarlası'nın amacı, boş kareleri açmak ve içlerinde mayın olanları açmaktan kaçınmaktır. Karede bir sayı görünürse, bu sayı içinde bulunduğu kareyi çevreleyen sekiz karede toplam kaç tane mayın olduğunu belirtir. 

Hatırladığım kadarıyla oyunda 3 tane gizli başarım var bunların ikisini şöyle açacaksınız;

author: {'steamid': '76561198135157290', 'num_games_owned': 765, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 539, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 246, 'last_played': 1684647566}
review:
[h1]一款更加高级的扫雷[/h1]
[quote=百度百科]扫雷，这个基于数字的逻辑谜题最早来自20实际六七十年代，当时候Jerimac Ratliff推出的名为“Cube”的游戏已经非常受人欢迎。几十年后的1992年，扫雷游戏被加入了Windows3.1，这并不是为了展示Windows是游戏操作系统专家，而是为了训练用户的鼠标左右键操作能力，让这些动作变得非常自然，并培养鼠标移动的速度和准确性。[/quote]
      
      它(Minesweeper)作为一款上个世纪发行的游戏，直到现在，仍然能够令一批又一批的玩家驻足于此，去体验这个简约而不失休闲的游戏。即使拥有着非常棒的创意和简单易上手的游戏内容，它也不免或多或少会有一些单调。

      于是，这款游戏(Fine Sweeper)的出现，极大的提高了扫雷本身的可玩性。一方面，这个游戏加入了stage game的游戏模式，可以让玩家玩从简单到困难逐步提高的关卡，而且可以在经典和正常两种模式下开始游玩。经典就是原先扫雷的玩法，一命过关；正常模式下，除了增添了血条，还出现有技能（说实话，我没怎么用过），也算是降低了游戏的单调性。对了，这个游戏在每一关会有分数的计算，越快时间通关给的分数加成越高，另外，整个关卡中不插旗子也会有分数加成。

       游戏总体来说，是对扫雷的扩展，实质上并没有什么新的花样。点到炸弹的音效倒是做的略带感/滑稽。

[h1]题外话——其实微软的Microsoft Minesweeper更加的耐玩些[/h1]

       相信现在很多朋友现在用的操作系统都是win10了，那么微软自家的[url=https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/store/p/microsoft-minesweeper/9wzdncrfhwcn]扫雷各方面重置版[/url]可能更加符合各位雷友长期游玩的要求（不要怪我啊，这并不是强行安利，毕竟的确很耐玩啊）

[h1]一些同类的小游戏推荐[/h1]

       如果这个游戏玩的无聊了，可以去试试[url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/265890/Hexcells/]Hexcells[/url]系列和[url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/416770/SquareCells/?snr=1_7_7_151_150_1]SquareCells[/url]，这两个游戏比扫雷更加着重于逻辑推断，不喜欢自带非欧鉴别功能的扫雷的朋友，可以去玩玩前面说的游戏，也是很不错而且画风清奇的“扫雷”。

author: {'steamid': '76561198204159008', 'num_games_owned': 338, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 374, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 374, 'last_played': 1484918311}
review:
This is Minesweeper with more than one life (the player can be granted up to seven lives at a time). As Minesweeper is half-deterministic and can be played as "classic mode" in Fine Sweeper as well, Fine Sweeper can be seen as an extended version of Minesweeper including an editor for random maps created from the following data: 
- Height (of the rectangle)
- Width  (of the rectangle)
- Number of bombs to encounter
The standard campaign, where the size of the randomized rectangles rises continuously with the number of bombs, is supposed to be played till level 51 and beyond, which, for friends of Minesweeper, signifies a clear recommendation.

author: {'steamid': '76561198063144502', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 29866, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11417, 'last_played': 1701553427}
review:
I'll admit that the original minesweeper from the 90's was my favorite way to procrastinate and waste time whenever I had important assignments due or serious finals to study for.  I've spent hours playing it straight into the wee hours of the morning only to realize at 6am that I was completely screwed because I hadn't yet started writing that essay or even cracked open a text book.  Nothing like turning on the computer with the very best of intentions and thinking "hey I'll just play one game to get my brain going before I get started" only to fail miserably every time.  Ah, the nostalgia...

If you were a fan of the original minesweeper, this game is a must have for your steam library.  It plays much like the original and has some added improvements which makes it even more addicting if you can believe it.  Multiple modes are included in the game, my favorite one being the campaign mode which progressively gets harder the more you advance.  I've long since collected every achievement in the game but I keep playing it because the challenge is so enjoyable .  

I find this game to be very satisfying and relaxing but I don't think everyone will feel the same way.  If you are on the fence about it, I would suggest playing the free 90's version first to see if you enjoy it at all.  If you don't, you likely won't like this one either.

UPDATE 11/26/17:  I am nominating this game for the "No Apologies" award category in the 2017 Autumn Awards.  As of today I am STILL playing this game, and no one I know in real life can understand why I'm so into it.  I don't really understand it either but the important thing is I'm still having fun and don't care what anyone thinks.  =)

author: {'steamid': '76561198028673669', 'num_games_owned': 7010, 'num_reviews': 401, 'playtime_forever': 181, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 181, 'last_played': 1455566767}
review:
The trailer says - Waste time like it's 92 - and you know what? This game as great as it was when you were playing Minesweeper 20 years go. Srsly, personally I always liked minesweeper more than solitary, and I was pretty skeptical about this game but:

+Visuals: Very nice design of the levels, colorful, every some levels it changes the color palette so you won't get bored, various settings, mmmm :3
+Gameplay: 1st of all the gameplay is a bit improved all around but not as much so you won't say it that this game is too casual or different from the original. You have the campaign to advance through multiple levels with increasing difficulties, you have a lot of achievements to beat, you can play with or without lives so if you fиck up on the last cornered mines you can continue playing. I like everything about this game seriously. All the old features like flags and left+right click detections are still here :)
+Sound work is okay
+Steam cards
+Steam achievements

So overall I enjoyed everything in this game and its also cheap AF AND it goes on sale sometimes so with the cards price you can obtain this gem nearly free.

review:
[h1]Fine Sweeper —— 好扫雷 [/h1]
基本玩法和Windows的扫雷一样

先说几个[b]史诗级[/b]加强
    +多条命，不再一失足成千古恨
    +有BGM和点击音效
    +检测时单击右键即可
（除了开荒，基本可以全程右键完成，[strike]很好地平衡了鼠标左右键的寿命[/strike]）
如果作为闲来无事的消遣，或者win10难民的庇护所，那“好骚雷”同学还是尚可的
我选择差评，是他们设置的成就自己作出来的

经典扫雷里最懊恼的是什么？无法推理必须二选一，多选一猜，然后瞬间爆炸
原本“好骚雷”里的生命值系统可以规避这一缺点
但是在Level 40之后，地雷数的剧增（远超经典高级99）让整个雷区极不稳定
走两三步一个二选一，命根本不支持你猜完。[b]垃圾游戏全靠运气[/b]
我脾气已经算好的了，还是玩到骂娘
（第一步可以踩雷这个设定也是相当清奇）

最后，我想对设置【踩5000个雷】和【插50000个旗】成就的制作组[b][url=http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=750890735] 诚挚地问候一句[/url][/b]

review:
[h1]Fine Sweeper est une version moderne du démineur[/h1]

Tous les trentenaires et quarantenaires ont joué au démineur dans leur bureau quand ils en avaient marre de bosser. C’est mon cas aussi. Mon patron ne l’a jamais su, heureusement. Il faut dire qu’aujourd’hui, c’est encore plus compliqué avec Internet !

Bref, Fine Sweeper est une version améliorée du démineur et ça a été un grand plaisir pour moi d’y rejouer.

Essayez le mode campagne. Vous commencez avec un niveau petit et simple et à chaque réussite, votre grille devient de plus en plus grande, de plus en plus difficile.

C’est malheureux à dire, mais ce sont encore des heures, des journées, des semaines de temps scotché devant l’ordinateur à déminer ces grilles !

[url=www.graal.fr/2016/05/07/test-fine-sweeper-la-version-pour-steam/]Pour découvrir l’ensemble des mes impressions sur Fine Sweeper.[/url]

author: {'steamid': '76561198093220384', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 148, 'playtime_forever': 1510, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1069, 'last_played': 1569222067}
review:
For those who've never run a Windows device, or are just too young to have really caught the original game in its prime, back in the day when you had to open a hatch and shovel coal in to power your PC, or sacrifice some of your blood into the little funnel on the top and get it to run for an extra 66.06 minute's worth of use, there were two games that were all the rage for everyone from the lowliest peasant to the wealthiest king, many of which would spend [i]literally[/i] millions on a new machine just to play them and nothing else. I am of course talking about Solitaire and Minesweeper. Solitaire has already seen several enjoyable re-workings, but now it's Minesweeper's time to shine with a modern update in the form of Fine Sweeper. And you know what?... It ain't half bad.

Presented with a grid full of square panels that are hiding several mines underneath, you click on a panel and reveal some blank spaces and some numbers. Each number represents how many mines surround that tile, and based on that information, you must deduce the locations of every mine and avoid them as you click and remove all the unoccupied panels on the board. With each cleared grid, you move on to another that's either bigger and/or has more mines hiding from you. Make a mistake and you'll have a fully primed ball explode in your face. Do that several times, and it's game over.

The difference with this update is it's far more lenient than its original granddaddy. You now have hearts that allow you some breathing room where each heart will give you a free pass should you click on a mine, more of which can be found hiding under some random squares that can be used to replenish your stock and give you more room for mistakes. Or, alternatively, instead of using them you can save them in a bank and eventually cash them in for special, one-time use abilities to help you clear the board. And for hardcore score enthusiasts, this version has scoreboards for you, too, along with additional methods of play available to maximise that goal.

A little extra flair is added with some clean, appealing visuals (the grid and its surrounding boarder resembling the top-down dungeons from the original NES Zelda) and some funky bass licks to keep the mood up from stage to stage. It's all perfectly pleasant and functional and serves as a nice, relaxed, modern take on a fun but dated classic. I'm not sure how many stages there are, as I stopped at the 50 required for the achievements, but with multiple stages of increasing difficulty, a custom mode with sliding scales of variables, and a sweet little price to boot, for fans of Minesweeper, whatever your flavour is, this has you covered. Although, even in this updated version, clicking on the wrong mine in a final 50/50 situation and wasting the past 20 minutes of your life never stops hurting.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026786565', 'num_games_owned': 971, 'num_reviews': 165, 'playtime_forever': 486, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 380, 'last_played': 1461212383}
review:
[h1][b]Revitalizando um clássico[/b][/h1]

Fine Sweeper, game indie, casual que apresenta uma versão bem interessante do clássico game Campo Minado para o Windows, desenvolvido e distribuído pelo estúdio Pixel Prophecy, lançado em maio de 2015 para os PCs. 

Para quem é jogador da velha guarda e que sempre gostou de jogar qualquer coisa que estivesse disponível, com toda a certeza já deve ter jogado, ao menos uma vez, nem que seja por poucos minutos o clássico Campo Minado no Windows, Fine Sweeper nada mais é do que uma releitura desse clássico, com uma nova roupagem e algumas funcionalidades extras.

Para quem nunca jogou, o game é bem simples, basicamente o jogador deve marcar as minas em um tabuleiro, sem cometer o erro de clicar nas mesmas, para isso ele deve observar os números que são apresentados ao se clicar nos quadrados do tabuleiro, que indicam quantas minas existem ao seu redor, por exemplo caso o jogador encontre um número um, isso indica que apenas uma mina existe ao redor do número, se encontrar o número dois, duas minas e assim por diante. Um game bem simples, mas para os que querem entender de forma mais clara as regras do jogo Fine Sweeper apresenta um tutorial em slideshow que auxilia nisso. 

Basicamente é o mesmo jogo que conhecemos no Windows, com as mesmas mecânicas, porem com algumas adições interessantes, como a inclusão de vidas, que são perdidas a cada erro e podem ser recuperadas ao longo dos níveis, ou a inclusão dos modos Clássico e Campanha. Mas o mais interessante é que o game funciona em níveis, os primeiros níveis são bem fáceis e rápido de serem concluídos, podendo ser finalizados em segundos, mas conforme se avança os tabuleiros vão ficando cada vez maiores e com uma quantidade alta de minas, o que deixa as partidas mais longas demandando uma boa dose de atenção e paciência do jogador. 

De maneira geral, Fine Sweeper é uma excelente game casual, que consegue fazer jus ao game que se baseia, dando uma bela revitalizada em algo que já era bom. Logicamente esse é um game simples, indicado para os amantes de jogos causais e para os saudosista de plantão, que assim como eu se divertiram jogando o clássico Campo Minado. 

[b]Informações adicionais:[/b]
Nota geral: 08.
Tempo dedicado ao game: 8 horas.
Conquistas desbloqueadas: 13 de 19.
Dificuldade: Fácil, ficando mais difícil nos níveis mais altos, mas a dificuldade fica apenas na exigência de mais atenção do jogador.
Fica a dica: Apesar de ser extremamente casual, nos níveis mais elevados, o game exige um certo raciocínio logico do jogador, portanto preste bem atenção nas informações que o game lhe apresenta.
Gameplay: [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pZoqPNaU2e0]Clique aqui.[/url]
Imagens durante a jogatina: [url=http://steamcommunity.com/id/luishq/screenshots/?appid=367000]Clique aqui.[/url]
Vale o preço? Apesar de ser um preço razoavelmente baixo, talvez seja mais indicado pega-lo com um desconto de 50%.
Modo de jogo: Exclusivamente singleplayer.
Idioma: Totalmente traduzido para o português do Brasil.

[b]Originalmente publicado no [url=http://portohq.blogspot.com.br/2016/03/analise-games-fine-sweeper.html]Blog PortoHQ.[/url][/b]

review:
It's 2016. If you're not familiar with Minesweeper...I hope you wake from your coma eventually. If you hate Minesweeper, you're going to hate this. If you kinda like it, you'll most likely enjoy yourself here. If you dream of grids filled with flags and hidden bombs...this is a wet dream for you. It's [b]Minesweeper on steroids[/b]. Even at the full asking price it's worth the upgrade for fans of Minesweeper. On sale it's a no-brainer for even the most casual of minesweeping fans...

Pros -
[list]
[*] Campaign mode
[*] Choice between classic (single life) & updated (multiple 'hearts') mode
[*] Ability to restart from highest completed level
[*] Some neat power-ups
[/list]

Cons - 
[list]
[*] Music is rather repetitive...not bad...just repetitive
[*] Effects from explosions can make it hard to see tiles. Especially frustrating when you're going for speed on a level.
[/list]

review:
기존 윈도우 상의 지뢰찾기와 진행방식은 비슷합니다. 어차피 지뢰찾기니까요. 
더 화려해?졌고, 중간에 하트를 획득하면 획득한 수만큼 몫이 늘어나 지뢰가 터져도 게임을 계속할 수 있다는 점, 클리어 시간과 성공률이 아닌 점수로 기록되는 전체렝킹이 있다는 점(지정한 레벨부터 시작해 클리어 시 한단계씩 올라가며 점수를 더해가는데 이 점수의 총합이 얼만지 기록하는 것 같더군요.) 정도였던 것 같습니다. 
lv40까지는 별로 어렵지 않게 클리어 가능한 것 같은데 그 이상에 도달하면 지뢰 수가 많이 늘어나 힘드네요. 제 경우 60근처로 가면 하트 없인 클리어가 많이 어려웠습니다. 
윈도우10으로 바뀌며 기존의 지뢰찾기가 그리우셨다면 좋은 선택일 것 같습니다. 
그리고 제 경우엔 커서가 잘 안보여서 불편한 감이 있네요.

author: {'steamid': '76561198133884906', 'num_games_owned': 1161, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 178, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 76, 'last_played': 1451818748}
review:
嗯这款游戏可是类似神作扫雷的！而且还有关卡设定！买买买买买 (/≧▽≦/)
[spoiler] sweeper好像有清洁工的意思..emm,fine sweeper[/spoiler]
游戏入过包，我接触到这款游戏的游戏就是买了慈善包XD，商店价格貌似有点太高了.
游戏玩法和扫雷几乎没有区别，进游戏右上角是一个计时器，右边有这个关卡有几个炸弹和你已经放了几个旗帜（似乎仅适用于战役模式），不过有一点值得吐槽，就是有一定几率你刚开始第一关的时候随便点了一下，发现过关了（这居然还有个成就，春看人品呀QAQ）
总之没事干的时候拿来消磨时间还不错，不过对我来说很难深入玩下去（因为手残），具体关卡数不清楚，而且貌似有的关卡能让你拥有2点及以上的生命值，应该够玩很长时间的(′・ω・`)
游戏性：7/10 让人较难深入玩下去，不过拿来打发时间还不错
音乐：5/10 音乐有点让人难以接受..在游戏中有点稍显多余..
剧情：无（这种游戏怎么会有剧情≡￣﹏￣≡
画质：8/10 画风对于一款小游戏来说可以接受
总评：7/10 在小游戏里算是不错的一款，买来不只是+1挂卡，偶尔玩玩还是不错的/w\,不过建议听音乐玩，这游戏的音乐确实有点毁了这款作品的意思..

review:
Minesweeper is back, because Windows without Minesweeper wouldn't be Windows. This game is a remake of the classical Minesweeper, found on Windows computers ever since the dawn of man, until Microsoft (wrongly) decided we didn't need it. It adds new stuff like lives and a sort of campaign mode that gets progressively harder. It also has the option to turn it into classic mode, in which there are no extra lives.

Another thing it adds are leaderboards, so you can compete with your friends.

It's quite good, and it has a nice jazzy soundtrack to get you in a minesweeping mood. I don't know what more to say in this review, only that if you're looking for a good Minesweeper replacement, look no further!

review:
At last.
My pathetic skills on minesweeper are put to use.

On a serious note, the game is pretty nice, very nice effects, colorful, is quite forgiving and has a nice feeling to it. The only thing is that the songs aren't very... memorable, to put it simply.

As for the modes, You have a sort of "adventure" mode where you have 3 hearts, and you complete levels as fast as you can, with increasing difficulty. You can gather more hearts up to a maximum of 7.
Then there's your good old classic mode, where you can set the size of the grid and amount of bombs as you like.
There's global and friend leaderboards for each mode.

Is it worth it? Sure, as long as you get it for a really cheap price like I did.

All in all I give this game a 9/10. Grab it if you liked minesweeper.

author: {'steamid': '76561198063739378', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 462, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 462, 'last_played': 1448959058}
review:
Well, first, it's Minesweeper. If you're not in to the game in general, this version of it is unlikely to change your mind.

If you do like it, however, this is one of the better versions around. They offer a "classic mode" which is pretty similar to the original Windows version, and their own variation which is arguably better. I'll concentrate on that in the remainder of this review.

The major change is that you now get lives (hearts), of which you can have up to seven, allowing you to detonate seven bombs before the game terminates. Extra lives are dropped as you progress so if you're careful you should be able to handle five or so detonations per level indefinitely. While some might lament the loss of tension in this mechanic as compared to the traditional "instant game over" from a single detonation, there are situations where you simply can't know which of two possible layouts you're looking at, and you have to guess. Being able to do this makes the game less luck- and more skill-based, and also introduces the new mechanic of figuring out, when you do have to risk exploding something, what will leave you in the best shape after that move.

Along these lines too, they also appear to have removed both any chance of detonating a mine on your first move and the possibility of first moves that don't open the board enough for you to make an intelligent next move, as opposed to a guess. (I presume they do this by building the board only after you've chosen your first move.) Again, this shifts the game away from luck and more towards skill.

The standard "campaign" game has you clearing levels, starting with a small (5x5) grid where you need to flag three bombs, and eventually moving up to a full 20x40 grid with dozens of bombs. This gives a nice feeling of progression, and also makes things rather interesting and different from the original gameplay once you reach level forty, where you have to deal with a much higher bomb density (hundreds) than the original game ever offered. You can stop playing at any time and it will restart where you left off when you come back to the game. If your game ends, and you restart again from the main menu, you'll be prompted to start at any level you like up to the highest level you've ever reached.

The graphics are pretty decent, without being distracting, and I particularly appreciated their well done auto-open highlight. I use it a lot, and it's nice that it's easy to read in this game. (Auto-open is when you middle or right click an open cell to automatically open all non-flagged cells around it. If you don't have exactly the number of surrounding cells flagged as indicated in the cell on which you're clicking, you'll see a highlight of all unopened cells, allowing you to quickly and easily concentrate on the ones you need to flag.)

Custom modes, where you set the board size and number of bombs, are also available, and there's are also simple global and friends list leaderboards for comparing your score (which appears to be based on several factors, including what you expose and how many bombs you explode, but not on time taken). There's also a reasonable selection of achievements, and Steam trading cards.

All in all, this is a nice little time killer, and at $3 or less I think it's priced perfectly for what it is.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993437321', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 168, 'playtime_forever': 1089, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 391, 'last_played': 1665825209}
review:
A nice presentation of Mine Sweeper with a couple of nice, new features.

Auto-Clearing Option:
If you right-click on a cleared tile with a number (indicating how many bombs in it's surrounding tiles), and you have that number of marked tiles surrounding this number tile, all un-marked tiles will auto-clear.  Just be sure you marked the right tiles or the revealed bomb will detonate.  If you do not have the correct number of marked/flagged tiles around a number tile you can safely right-click on it to hilight the surrounding tiles and no new tiles will clear.  This feature increases the flow of the game tremendously.

Health:
Each time you detonate a bomb, you will lose a heart.  Lose all of your heats and it's game over.  When clearing tiles, replacement hearts will randomly appear as well as extra heart tiles to increase your total number of hearts up to seven.  I really like this approach, but I feel the game is too generous with how many hearts it gives you.  This makes the game a bit too easy.  It removes the tension you normally get when you play classic Mine Sweeper and you don't know if you are a mouse-click away from your explosive doom.

Graphics:
Simple space background graphics.  The planets are drawn crudely.  Subtle animated smoke and dust effects when tiles are cleared and when bombs detonate.  There is room for improvement, however:  Early levels (below 35 or so) have fewer total tiles.  The smaller tile graphics from later levels are used in these early levels and scaled up.  This makes the graphics look soft.  After you reach level ~35 everything looks sharper because everything is displayed in actual size.  Separate, larger tiles should have been created for these early levels so the graphics could look just as sharp as they look in later levels.  The entire game download is under 60 megabytes.  The developer had no reason not to create an extra set of larger tiles.

Aside from the soft graphics I meantioned just one paragraph ago (Remember?), the presentation is decent.  It could have looked even better with more dynamic lighting.  The tiles in this game are all evenly lit making them look like they could have been presented on a 16-bit console (other than the smoke and particle effects). 

The game does present some fun graphics pop-ups that appear with certain achievements along with animated fireworks.  If you have any achievements in Pinball FX2 you know exactly what I am talking about.

The game has modes other than classic mine sweeper, but I have not tried them yet.  I've reached level 38 in the main game and I can easily recommend this game for it's low price, clean presentation and the auto-clearing feature.

review:
Enfin un démineur moderne! Les adeptes des jeux de puzzle/réflexion comme moi seront ravis par ce jeu.

J'aime beaucoup le style graphique et la bande-son qui est à la fois calme et groovy. Le créateur du jeu met souvent "Fine Sweeper" à jour (correction de bugs, optimisation, nouvelles fonctionnalités, etc). Le jeu est infini. review: Great to see this piece of nostalgia get polished up with some more style.  However I am hitting my head against a minor usability flaw (as I see it) which is preventing my full appreciation.  When you click on a bomb, that bomb is replaced by a number and other numbers near it change as a result.  I understand the concept of "it blew up so it's not there anymore", but I'm not sure this behavior really adds much to the game.  In fact, 1) I have to question now what a number on an exploded bomb means, which can get confusing as you ponder whether to count the square its on, and 2) when you're deep in analysis of board state and click on a bomb, now your numbers have all changed making it a) really annoying to figure out WHY you made a mistake ("Now, what were those #'s??") and b) forces you to recalculate other moves you were pondering in the area.  I don't think that was actually your intended goal, but for me it jolts the user out of his/her focus.  Additionally, you don't need the number that replaces the bomb anyway, a person is trying their hardest to avoid all those locations already.  Would be nice to toggle this behavior in options so bombs you click on just stay... bomb blasts and no numbers appear or change.  But overall thanks for the game!

author: {'steamid': '76561198062674571', 'num_games_owned': 5359, 'num_reviews': 214, 'playtime_forever': 1192, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1187, 'last_played': 1438246883}
review:
Fine Sweeper to remake klasycznego Sapera, znajdującego się prawie na każdym komputerze osobistym. Naszym zadaniem w grze jest odsłonięcie wszystkich pól prostokątnej planszy, uważając, żeby nie trafić na minę. Na każdym odkrytym polu znajduje się numer, przedstawiający ilość min z nim sąsiadujących, na podstawie którego musimy ustalić, gdzie znajdują się kolejne wybuchowe niespodzianki. Dodatkowo pola możemy flagować, zabezpieczając je przed przypadkowym odsłonięciem. Czy jest coś, czym można udoskonalić te prostą formułę gry?

Okazuje się, że tak. I nie chodzi tu tylko o ładną i stylową oprawę graficzną, jaką oferuje Fine Sweeper. Rozgrywka w omawianym tytule przyjmuje postać swoistej kampanii, w której mierzymy się z coraz większymi i coraz gęściej zaminowanymi planszami. Ponadto wprowadzono system żyć, dzięki któremu możemy kilka razy pomylić się podczas zabezpieczania pola minowego. Życia tracimy odkrywając zaminowane pola, a zdobywamy, podnosząc serduszka ukryte pod niektórymi polami. Takie rozwiązanie może się z początku wydawać sporym ułatwieniem, ale sprawdza się ono bardzo dobrze podczas kampanii, a szczególnie w późniejszych poziomach, kiedy często nie możemy jednoznacznie ustalić, gdzie jest mina i zmuszeni jesteśmy do zgadywania. Jeśli kogoś to nie przekonuje, to może po prostu zagrać w trybie klasycznym, w którym gra kończy zaraz się po natrafieniu na pierwszą minę, tak jak w oryginalnym Saperze. Podzielenie rozgrywki na kolejne, coraz trudniejsze poziomy daje większą motywację do gry, przez co Fine Sweeper potrafi wciągnąć na dłużej niż zwykły Saper. Sporym plusem są też globalne rankingi, dzięki którym możemy porównać nasze wyniki w grze ze znajomymi i graczami z całego świata. W grze dodano też kilka usprawnień rozgrywki, np. szybkiego odsłaniania wszystkich nieoflagowanych pól wokół tego klikniętego albo możliwość zapisania stanu rozgrywki, co bardzo przypadło mi do gustu.

Jedyną rzeczą, która mi się nie spodobała, to to, że w późniejszej części gry zbyt często nie możemy określić, gdzie dokładnie jest mina i możemy tylko zaryzykować i strzelić. Jakoś to współgra z systemem żyć, a niektórzy twierdzą nawet, iż element ryzyka wpływa na korzyść rozgrywki. Jednak osobiście oczekiwałem, że gra będzie nagradzać spostrzegawość i myślenie, a nie szczęście i zniechęcało mnie to do dalszego grania. Oprócz tego w grze zdarzają się spadki płynności. Raczej nie przeszkadzają i wręcz trudno je zauważyć, ale coś takiego w takiej produkcji dziwi.

Podsumowując, Fine Sweeper to klasyczny Saper w ładniejszej oprawie i z szeregiem innowacji, nadającym znanej wszystkim rozgrywce więcej sensu i zachęcającym do spędzenia przy niej nieco więcej czasu. Właśnie tak powinien wyglądać Saper.

review:
This game is a really hardcore yet casual version of Minesweeper. It sticks to the well-known basics of the game, but brings it to a far grander scale, the only item drops that the description mentions being extra lives (and some canisters to hold your extra lives early on), which is just as it should be.

And you'll need them all, you really will, the global 'record' seems to be level 67 right now which only two people have gotten, and I'm currently working on level 59, and I'm facing a 36x22 board with 219 bombs to flag and 7 lives (plus any others you find on the map) to do it with.

You'll learn so many new tricks and logical leaps out of necessity as to how to figure out the status of squares and try to narrow down the number of 50-50 guesses you have to make, which is why you have that many lives. It's a really engaging non-time-constrained puzzle game, exactly the kind of game that I love running in the background while I do or watch other stuff. Who knew Minesweeper could be so fun?

I didn't run into any bugs or glitches or have any complaint about the UI of the game. Yet. (Edit: I now have run headlong into a fairly major bug but the devs seem responsive and are working on it. (Edit: They fixed it!)) The one background tune it has is also a nice, non-intrusive, non-obnoxious track so I've left it on even after nearly 24h of off-and-on play.

author: {'steamid': '76561198100994885', 'num_games_owned': 1826, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 15271, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 13827, 'last_played': 1585627027}
review:
50 hours in and I think it's time to write a review. Been playing it on and off rather addictively for the last month or so, most of that due to my unrelenting addiction for minesweeper (and achievements) as well as just wanting to top those leaderboards to make my life seem less worthless...

This is the best minesweeper remake I've ever played, it is a hell of a lot better then the windows remake that was on the windows store (not sure if they actually made it) which was a tragedy.
Like that one this too had pickups, which is an obviously new addition to the classic minesweeper formula and whilst I was pretty skeptical at first it's a very well incorporated addition unlike the other version. There is also classic mode where you only have 1 life and therefore you hit a bomb you die (just like in real life!).

This game has unlimited levelling (until I assume the board is literally just mines) but post level 60, odds are you're going to find it very hard to complete it. This put me off a little at first, since the game then revolved too heavily on luck and not skill but then if it'd be far too easy if everything was solvable by skill, there's not much to really make harder regarding skill in minesweeper.
The sheer difficulty of the higher levels have made me a much better player as I was forced to find new ways and rules to find bombs, which is something games won't normally do!

The graphics are nice but not too distracting and veer too far from the original minecraft, in other words there is nothing over the top and 'included because it's eye candy and omg luk at dem 4k textures'... Sounds are fine, bombs give a nice explosion (and leave a crater in the board) which can be quite unnerving when you're really focusing which brings a lot of tension to the game.

The devs seem to very active, I've seen a lot of activity in the forums from them and they seem to answer and adress the majority of problems that appear which is great. They seem to really care about the game and are not looking for quick monies, especially considering the price!

For £1.99 this is a steal, I think I got this in a greenlight bundle so I paid a lot less and feel like I robbed the devs and also took there clothes but I'd pay at least full price considering I've got 50 hours out of it and I don't feel like I'm going to be uninstalling anytime soon (#1 spot on the leader board here I come!). Even if you are not human and didn't enjoy the original minesweeper, you should still pick this up if you even have the very least bit of passing interest in minesweeper. Recent update made the earlier levels a lot easier so it starts off as a very casual game, perfect for wasting time!

review:
(04/10) - At least playable

So what has this game going for it? There has to be something as it´s based on a free game that is furthermore already installed on every windows pc out there.
Well, there is a mode with more lives so you don´t die instantly, tho as a hardcore Minesweeper lover, that´s nothing for me.
One thing they did well is the first click: it is guaranteed to give you a start, and yes while this is not really innovative as other games did it as well by already revealing an area at the start, it´s definetly a feature that´s missing in Minesweeper...

Tho they forgot to change the biggest flaw of Minesweeper. If they had done that, i´d blindly recommend the game to anyone who likes Minesweeper... but they didnt: You still have to guess.
The more mines you add, the higher the probability of you having to guess meaning that the later stages will have a near to 100% chance that you will need to guess AT LEAST once, if not more times.

And as in any game: the word random should not be able to describe the game. Be it Hearthstone (a Hearthstone referene from a Minesweeper review, yes i did it) or any other game, it will decrease the value by an extreme amount.
So no, i can´t recommend you to buy this game, as it´s essentially the same game as the free version you probably already have installed...

Note: You can´t tell me there is no algorithm for placing the bombs in a way that you don´t have to guess. "Hexcells: Infinite" did it and they had a far more complex ruleset to work with. So yeah, i will just keep waiting until someone may eventually release this game without having to guess, until then, play something else...

review:
It's a good Minesweeper remake! There are dozens of levels now instead of just three, Steam leaderboards to show off with, and the options and controls are just like how you remember them. (Plus, it's got a nice background track that sounds roughly like a cat playing Team Fortress 2.)

That being said, Minesweeper is much more boring than I remember it. It's mostly just a game of matching: spotting which numbers on the board are equal to the amount of adjacent tiles or flagged mines. The only real puzzle aspect to Minesweeper comes when you've spotted all the possible matches, and the only way to progress is to use some deductive reasoning on the remaining numbers. But no matter how hard you try, if there are too many mines clustered together in the wrong way, you're eventually going to have to start guessing, and that's ultimately Minesweeper's biggest downfall.

Luckily, Fine Sweeper gives you lives, so you can step on multiple mines on a level and still keep going. This introduces a completely new skill to the game: when stuck in a guessing situation, instead of just clicking and hoping you don't die, you have to pick the option that would give you the most useful information in a single click. It's a pretty nice touch and it feels like a good evolution of the game of Minesweeper.

But eventually the game starts cranking up the number of mines, enough to remind you of that one time you thought it would be hilarious to make a custom Minesweeper game with the maximum amount of mines, and then soon realized it was completely pointless and impossible. Despite the designer's attempts to balance the difficulty, it's inevitable in Minesweeper that you're going to have to guess a whole lot. But that's a problem with Minesweeper itself, and so this remake shouldn't really be held accountable for it. 

Although, it makes me wonder if the level generator could have included a bot that plays through the stage before it is presented, to make sure there are no necessary guesses. Or if there could be seeded boards with an automatic first click that are verified possible without guessing. But even though Fine Sweeper doesn't go all-out in bringing Minesweeper into the HD age, it's still good enough to be worth your time if you were, or still are, a huge fan of the old Windows games; it is a notable improvement on them.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970476640', 'num_games_owned': 304, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 1934, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 349, 'last_played': 1575473205}
review:
Fine Sweeper is, well, Minesweeper, but with some changes which I found to enhance the basic experience. The game is immediately familiar to anyone who’s played Minesweeper, and it also has a tutorial for anyone who hasn’t.

The main mode of the game is a “campaign” style mode – you basically start with a tiny board to clear, and each time you win you progress to a slightly more difficult board (the backgrounds and colors vary as well). Pretty soon (and I do mean soon, it doesn’t take long to progress through the early levels) you’ll be playing on boards even more difficult than the “Expert” boards from Minesweeper. As you play through the campaign, you earn points for each mine you flag and each board you clear – and you can compare your scores to other players’ on the leaderboards.

This leads me to my only complaint – there’s no way to save your campaign progress. When you quit the campaign, your score is reset. You can still start at the highest level you’ve unlocked, but your score starts at zero. A single save slot would allow you to continue the game through more than one session.

As you play, you randomly unlock and find lives, which are used up whenever you detonate a mine. This single-handedly fixes the main frustration I have with Minesweeper – there’s no second chance if you guess wrong. Of course, once you run out of lives your game is over, but at least some of the frustration has been alleviated.

Custom game boards are included, so you’re able to create your own challenges. And if you’re not a fan of the new lives mechanic, you can play in “Classic” mode to disable it. The developer has proven to be very responsive as well, pushing out updates quickly and regularly based directly on community feedback.

Fine Sweeper provides a comprehensive Minesweeper package and improves on the classic. It’s more than worth the low price point.

Full [url=http://www.thesewall.com/?p=569]review[/url].

review:
If you gonna remake a game witch is free, and comes with windows by default, you really need to make it a lot better than the original game. Is this game better then original? It has some things going for it, but overall i would say no, and would recommend to play the windows version. 

Good side is live mechanic, which makes the 50/50 things little more forgiving. Almost every game of windows minesweeper at expert ends with at least one coin flip, usually around corners. Plus, maybe i'm just hallucinating, but in Fine Sweeper i had less coin flip situations.

However, the issue I have with the game is that the cursor snaps to grid, which makes controls really weird, and caused most deaths for me, or I end up wasting a lot time to correct a mistake, if I noticed it before next click. Also I don't like game graphic style. If anyone showed me a screenshot of a game, I would probably say that it was pre-windows version of game for DOS. But perhaps this is just me.

Anywhos, overall overall i would give this game 5/10, with windows minesweeper being at 8/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561197967419832', 'num_games_owned': 1365, 'num_reviews': 193, 'playtime_forever': 322, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 108, 'last_played': 1678512284}
review:
It's pretty much a pretty version of Minesweeper, but you have extra lives, up to 7 maximum, so you can hit up to 7 bombs before losing, and you can also find health pickups when uncovering tiles so you can refill your lives 1 at a time. Of course, there's also Classic mode, which is without the lives like the original Minesweeper.

There's some convenience features, like if there's already a marked bomb next to a "1" for example, you can right click the "1" to auto reveal all tiles around it. Of course, if you marked the wrong tile you'll hit a bomb, but it makes things quite more fluid. Also, they altered it a bit so that the first click on a level  [b]never[/b] hits a bomb. 

You start at level 1, and as you beat levels it gets increasingly harder and harder. Once you've beaten a level, you can choose to start at that level so you don't need to start at the beginning every time.

My only complaint is that you cant save games in progress, so if you want to start at level 1 and see how far you can get, you have to finish that challenge in one sitting, else you'll either have to start over, or start at the last level you remember, which resets the score.

If you like Minesweeper, then this game is definitely worth the cheap price.

author: {'steamid': '76561198060597598', 'num_games_owned': 3293, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 13, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 13, 'last_played': 1434734951}
review:
Let's not beat around the bush - it's just Minesweeper with a facelift.

It has a couple of flaws: it does have an element of chance in it rather than logic as there are some cases where there is no telling which of two cells has the mine underneath, and due to the progression you kind of just have to keep playing until you tire (which for me happened about 20 levels in, way before I felt in any real danger of losing). It also starts out very easy and takes a long time to build up to any real difficulty, although that is a matter entirely of personal preference.

On the other hand, if the idea of a game of minesweeper with a few app-like elements (added lives, some sort of social score thing popping up telling you how far ahead of other players you are etc.) appeals to you then this is a good implementation of this.

Overall, I'd say go for the Hexcells series if you want carefully crafted, more cerebral levels with absolutely no guessing and a higher difficulty threshold, but if you just want to sit and click in a faster-paced way then this may be the game for you. It's kind of the Bejeweled Blitz of Minesweeper clones.

review:
ルールはWindows同梱のマインスイーパーと同じだが、基本モードが面クリア型+ライフ制になっているのが大きな違い。ライフは時々出るハートによって回復することが可能になっている。クリア箇所はセーブされており途中の面からスタートすることも可能。ライフ制ではなくWin同梱版同様に一発アウトのルールにすることも可能。[strike]（おそらくだが）爆弾の箇所を開けたら即終了となるWindows同梱版と同じルールにすることは不可能。[/strike]自分でカスタムの難易度（縦横の幅、爆弾の数の変更）でプレイすることも可能。

steamに出すなら抑えておいて欲しい要素（実績、トレカ、フレンドとのスコアランキング）は抑えているので安心。バッジを作るのに必要なカードが6枚（うち3枚はドロップ）というのもうれしい。スコアランキングは最初からスタートした場合も途中からスタートした場合も同列に扱ったランキングになっているので、別にモードを設けて欲しかった気もする。

Win7 32bitの環境ではWin7同梱のマインスイーパーのメモリ消費量が40MBに対してこれは120MBだったので少々起動が重い気がしなくもない。

個人的には爆弾の場所が確定している時に周りのマス目を一気に開く方法が左右クリック同時押しではなく、右クリックあるいは真ん中クリックだけでできることがよかった。ただし高レベルになってマス目が細かくなると誤爆しやすいと感じる人もいるかもしれない。（※2015/06/18現在ベータ版限定ですが、Win同梱版同様に左右同時クリックにすることも可能だそうです）

review:
Не думал я, что могу запутаться в описании "Сапёра", но мне это удалось.

Что говорит описание на сайте? "Сапёр с новыми фичами, такими как режим кампании, предметами, ачивками и таблицей рекордов!"

Что есть? Вот именно оно и есть. Описание - исчерпывающее. Единственное, что в нём не сказано - это то, что режим кампании состоит во всё растущих досках со всё увеличивающимся количеством мин, а "предметы" - это жизни-сердечки, которые можно взять до 7 штук - и всё. А, и что таблица рекордов допускает ровно одно вхождение, поэтому весёлые надписи "Вы обогнали [рандомного чувака ХХХ]!" вы будете видеть только при первой игре - или побив свой собственный предыдущий рекорд.

Я, честно говоря, почему-то ждал большего.

Ну, да ладно. В целом - нормальный "Сапёр". За копейки взять можно, особенно учитывая, что можно включить "классический" режим, и что в моей Windows 8 и такого-то нет.

P.S. А ещё автор не сбалансировал размер досок с количеством бомб, в результате прохождение этапов после, этак, сорокового становится тем ещё испытанием для нервов: угадывать нужно в среднем раз пять-шесть за этап. Лично меня хватило до 50-го, и я плюнул. Но в "новостях" он пообещал уже это поправить в будущем. Посмотрим...

You progress through levels of increasing difficulty and best of all it's very forgiving of mistakes and accidents because you have a handful of lives (hearts) plus random chances of finding more hearts under the tiles. Alternating color schemes for each level keep things fresh and some of the achievements are quite a challenge.

It's a light game but if you're a fan of Minesweeper then the small price is absolutely worth it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996953889', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 678, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 596, 'last_played': 1433798431}
review:
How good are you at coin flipping?

That's what the more advanced stages of this game hinge on.

In campaign mode, starting around level 20, you're not going to be able to sweep an entire board without guess work.  Granted, you're going to have better than 50/50 odds on lots of guesses, but many guesses are no more than straight coin flips.  At level 20, the game stops being about skill, and transforms into a game of luck, whether it's if you can run hot at coin flipping, or whether you're fortunate enough to encounter lots of arbitrary heart health drops when you get in trouble.  Reaching level 20 in campaign mode is elementary for a skilled player, and since your health is fully replenished every ten levels (you receive full health at the start of level 20), plowing through levels 1 through 19 becomes tiring and is a pointless chore (but a necessary chore since if you're aiming for a high score, starting at level 1 will earn you the most cumulative points).  In levels 1 through 19, there is no reason to be careful with your clicks, not only because of too frequent health drops, but because at level 20 you're going to get all your health back anyway.

The one quantifier which made the original Minesweeper competitive, speed, seems to be completely neglected in this game.  I can't see any correlation between how fast you can sweep a board and scoring a higher number of points.

I've played more Minesweeper in my life than I care to admit; my fastest time on "Expert" in the Windows game is somewhere barely over 60 seconds.  As of the June 3rd writing of this review, I have the fourth highest campaign score on the leaderboard at 379,984.  That score would be a lot lower if on that particular run for a time being a divine entity had not told me which tiles to guess, and would be higher if I didn't lose three straight 50/50 coin flips at the very end of a level, which prevented me from clearing that particular stage and getting a large bonus.  At its low price I think that most people will get good value out of this game, however not even the most enthusiastic of Minesweeper fans will be piling up a ton of hours on this game.

Recommendations I would make to the developers:
- Make heart drops less frequent in low levels (1-19), and a little more frequent in difficult levels (20+)
- Make the penalty for triggering a bomb greater, losing points for stepping on a bomb is meaningless if you can reclaim those same points by clicking on a heart
- Eliminate health being fully replenished on levels divisible by ten
- Have the time you take to clear the board reflected in a multiplier for your score, the faster your time the higher your multiple
- In campaign mode, sometimes after clearing a board, it will have me immediately repeat the same level, sometimes more than once.  I'm not sure why this is, but I don't see the point of it, and it becomes tedious, so I would recommend eliminating that feature.

review:
For $1.99, this game is perfectly fine as-is. If you like [i]MineSweeper[/i] than you already know exactly what you are getting. My only complaint is that the new additions actually make the game worse, in my opinion.

1. By adding a health mechanic, it adds more forgiveness with mistakes, but for seasoned [i]MineSweeper[/i] players this only means that you can plow through certain parts that you would otherwise have to logic out.

2. The music is sub-par.

There are many far better games to play in this genre. [i]HexCells[/i] is front and center for me. With [i]Fine Sweeper[/i], you can get yourself into situations where you have to guess where a mine is, where in games like [i]HexCells[/i] there is NEVER a need for guessing.

Nothing makes [i]Fine Sweeper[/i] stand above its predecessor, and the new additions sound good, but don't translate well into the game.
developer_response: There's the "Classic Mode" where you have only one life and no health-pick ups if that's your kinda thing. If you don't like the music you can turn it off at any time.

review: Fine Sweeper is a superb Minesweeper variant, with great Steam integration: leaderboards, achievements, and trading cards. The game mechanics are similar to what you remember from the old Windows Minesweeper games, but with updated twists. A campaign mode has levels that get progressively harder, with cumulative scoring and timing. There are item drops, and you have the option to play in classic mode (in which hitting a mine will end the game and restart from the first level) or a mode in which you have multiple "lives" in which to carry on playing even if you hit an occasional mine. All of this is packaged in a slick interface, at least comparatively. Not everything is brand new though, it's every bit as addictive as the original.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040068728', 'num_games_owned': 2159, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 97, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 97, 'last_played': 1432930459}
review:
As much as I love minesweeper I just can't recommend this game. There isn't enough new and the new stuff isn't up to a good enough standard.

As soon as I saw this game on steam I had to buy it. I am a huge minesweeper fan and I just couldn't pass up a new version of it being released. However this game isn't much better than the original.

The main mode that this version features is a continuous mode. This mode continues going with levels of increasing difficulty. They basically increase the difficulty by growing the board size and adding more bombs. The score increases as a sum of all the levels you do and it measures the time you take on each level. This is incorperated into a high score system that lets you compare your score with friends and other people. This is a nice addition that gives a new reason to play minesweeper. 

However the problem with this mode is that there is no way to save it. I found myself going on a continuous run for over an hour earlier today. At that point I was getting pretty tired of it. I would have liked to quit the game and continue it later. But this wasn't possible since the game offers no way of saving it.

But this isn't the biggest problem the game has. It is horrible to play as you get further into the game with bigger boards. It is basically a guessing game at this point. Very little skill is involved. This is because the game puts you in situations where no amount of skill will let you figure out where there is a bomb and where there isn't so instead you just have to guess and hope for the best. I know this was a problem in the original minesweeper, but it definitely wasn't as big as a problem as it is in this game. When you get later into the game, i'd say around level 30ish, you start having to guess so often! This wasn't a fun experience and it isn't in the true light of minesweeper to have to guess instead of use skill.

The game does attempt to counteract this problem in a way. They use a life system. You find lives under blocks that you clear on the level which you can add to your collection. Everytime you hit a bomb you loose a life. Some people that are perhaps less skilled at minesweeper may like this addition. But to a hardcore player who has been playing for a long time this isn't of much use to me. I would much prefer to have only one life. I would prefer it if they would fix the guessing issue instead of using this lazy alternative to fix it. They don't even have an option to disable the life system which I would have done. 

What I used to love about the original minesweeper is the ginourmous size boards you could make and play on. Whenever I played it I used to make one of the biggest boards possible and then I would end up playing for about half an hour or so just on the one board. Fine sweeper features a similar mode to setup a custom sized board. But is no where near the scale that you can do on traditional minesweeper. In fact the boards are puny in size compared to the original. It's quite laughable to see it actually. Even when you go to the biggest scale possible. I have no idea why the developer limited it so much!

The options menu of the game is also extremely lacking. The only option of note is the audio sliders of which there is a seperate one for music and for other sounds. It's also probably worth noting that the music and sounds aren't particularly good in my opinion. I had them off for my entire time playing it. And the only other option there really is the nostalgic colours  option. That is it. They could at very least have some resolution options or something else!

There was only one thing in this game that I could find that may lead you to play this instead of the original minesweeper. The graphics. They are such an improvement over the classic original minesweeper. Although i'm sure you really need it to play a simple game like this. If only the developer could have put as much effort into making the game unique and work properly as they put in on the graphics!

Overall I cannot recommend this game. There are so many issues that it isn't actually fun to play. Theres not enough different for anyone to even consider playing it over the original. I am gonna go back to playing the original as well and I think you should to. I would also like to take the time here to recommend a great alternative to minesweeper that improves drastically on the original formula and of which I greatly enjoyed called "hexcells". If your a minesweeper fan and your wanting something new go and try that instead of this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198036028839', 'num_games_owned': 517, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 335, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 308, 'last_played': 1433440265}
review:
At it's base it's a polished version of Minesweeper with progression to feed gratification and lives to continue playing if you make a small hiccup.

Unfortunately, there are some negatives which I hope will be patched in at a later date, these would include:

First click not being an island--This is a fairly basic mechanic featured on some of the more simpler versions of Minesweeper found on the web. Not sure why this wasn't included from the start, since otherwise you are taking random guesses and unfairly losing lives (albeit there are some situations you have to guess no matter what, but the first click shouldn't be it).

When you set off a bomb it changes the numbers around the explosion--When this first happened and a 2 changed to a 1, I didn't realise and thought "Oh, so the bomb went off on the one so I'll free these other spaces around the 1" and then set off another bomb. Maybe some people prefer this but I feel like it's misleading and completely interrupts my flow and I have to re-read the board to make sure the numbers that may have changed don't have the appropriate amount of flags already.

Along with this, when a bomb explodes, the numbers underneath are barely readable. As well as numbers underneath heart pickups, and the very font to be honest is a bit poor. I would much prefer a clear-cut font like the font used to display the amount of bombs left on the map to be used, perhaps it can be a customisable option or something.

The Game Over screen completely covers the board when you die, which is frustrating because you can't see your mistake and learn from it. 

And finally, I looked at the 'things to come' screenshot quickly from the Dev (couldn't find a list of things he's patching otherwise I might have left some things off this list if he's patching them) but the colour contrast on the new colours for numbers looks quite poor and hard to read on darker levels--while not officially a thing that can be reviewed right now since it's not even in the game, I thought on the off-chance the dev reads this he can brighten up the colours for the numbers a bit.

Criticism aside, it's a nice looking iteration of Minesweeper and £1.59 isn't much to pay for a game which you can easily lose 30 mins or so of your day every time you load it, which adds up if you pace yourself. I would recommend, and I hope the dev updates it to become even more polished.

I would love to see more illustrations from the artist featured in the game some how too, they are quite lovely.

review:
Minesweeper is a classic. I think most people on the planet know of it's existence since Windows 95. It was once a way to cure boredom, something to do when parents were on the phone and stopped you from using the internet, or when the internet just decided to drop. Most people, at some point or another have played it for whatever reason..

Still with the same rule; avoid mines at all costs.

Now, it returns with an updated face, more levels, awesome sounds - along with a catchy tune to play it to and different backgrounds per game.

Return to the rage with Fine Sweeper. The original Minesweeper with a few extra twists that make it even more addictive but also more infuriating. Giving a little bit more of a chance to progress easier with life pick-ups and pick-ups to make your heart bar grow, it also comes adapted with; item drops, leader-boards, trading cards and achievements.

However, something they seem to have left out in Fine Sweeper is a good start, which I believe was introduced from Windows Vista on. While Fine Sweeper does seem to mostly prevent the first click from being a mine, it's quite likely that the clicked square is a 1 or greater, meaning you'll have to click somewhere else on the board randomly until you finally do find a good place to start, this was a slight embuggerance when it came to starting and instantly loosing a heart due to it being a bomb, or just hitting endless numbers higher than a 0.

None the less, new or old fan of Minesweeper, this is a great add to your library. Especially for all you Windows 8 people who miss out on the classic Minesweeper completely.

author: {'steamid': '76561198048947955', 'num_games_owned': 286, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 1257, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 138, 'last_played': 1614283854}
review:
Pixel Prophecy have updated the game and have with that fixed one of the major problems in the game (and a few others too!). I would like to say to anyone considering buying this game that this game is not a big Minesweeper overhaul or improvement: it just adds a neat little feature to it.

While my biggest complaint has been fixed, a few other do remain. This would include the lack of statistics (e.g. games played/won/lost; I do not mean a leaderboard), the ability to replay the same level (without the level regenerating), the ability to look at the board after having lost a game (to see what went wrong; currently a message box saying 'Game Over' is in the way) and lastly a fix for unsolvable levels.
These first three functions have been included in earlier versions of Microsoft Minesweeper, but the fourth one would definitely be a big improvement over Microsoft's game.

Of course, the game also has functions that Microsoft did not put in their game, namely multiple lives (clicking a mine does not end the current game) , online leaderboards, achievements and a variety of levels.

Perhaps that these things will be fixed/added with the next patch. But until then, I can say that I would recommend Fine Sweeper, keeping in mind that Microsoft Minesweeper is still a strong rival.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993661434', 'num_games_owned': 7148, 'num_reviews': 144, 'playtime_forever': 59, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 39, 'last_played': 1432628427}
review:
[H1]Oh sweeper you're so fine, you're so fine you blow my mind, hey sweeper! Hey sweeper...[/H1]

Fine sweeper, a game that some would say has been a long time coming, and a game that really should have been done by now. A simple, clean modernisation of Minesweeper. It has mines, it has sweeps, it has some nice extra features, it has music, it has a couple of really fun animations (the mines go boom), the playfields change as you work your way through the levels.

[H1]The Minesweeper we wanted, and the Minesweeper we deserved...[/H1]

It's Minesweeper. The core gameplay is as old as the hills so I won't belabour that. What's been added, well, aside from the classic game mode, the "Fine Sweeper" mode gives you lives, so if you accidentally blow a mine it may not be the end of the day, you may carry your lives between levels, giving you up to a maximum of seven do-overs before the game ends, and you may retry up to the last level you failed on. The custom mode allows you to set the size of the field and the number of mines, so that's pretty standard, and it has the basic options for sound and music (yes, we have music AT LAST, and it's pretty good).

[H1]Finely swept and finely polished...[/H1]

Considering this could have been a simple retooling of Minesweeper with a marginal graphics polish, Fine Sweeper has actually been a very pleasant surprise, it feels like a genuine coat of polish has been applied and it feels a lot more up to date from the original that we've been used to seeing on almost every version of Windows since day dot. Considering the price is absolutely minimal, this makes it a very nice value proposition for anyone looking for a "premium" minesweeper experience. Seriously, it's a good deal, try it!

Verdict : [b]Highly Recommended[/b]

review: Ok, I was really hoping this would be what it said on the tin - a fine version of Minesweeper. And on most accounts it is, with visually appealing graphics, increasing difficulty, a life system, and an actually included right click number mechanic (although that really should be double left click). However, there is one major flaw. In Minesweeper, the first square you click should always be an empty space. [b]Every. Single. Time.[/b] This accomplishes two things - one, making sure you don't hit a bomb on your first click, and second, setting up the rest of the board so you don't have take a leap of faith on you're second click. Somehow, the developer managed to miss this crucial game mechanic, that quite frankly makes the game infuriating and unplayable without. This game also suffers from a lack of features, some promised and some that can be found on free javascript versions online. The promotional video promises "heath pick ups and power ups," but only delivers on the first of those promises. The so called "custom" game mode only allows a laughable 18x11 grid. It has a pause function, but the only way it can be activated is if the window looses focus. Since I would not recommend anyone wasting $2 on this unfinished game, and you've made it this far, if you're looking for a minesweeper with more features and customization then you know what to do with, I'd suggest Mines from Simon Tatham's Portable Puzzle Collection. If you're looking for a visually appealing and highly polished version of minesweeper, go download Microsoft's version from the windows store. We're not stuck in 1992.
developer_response: Since the first patch your first click in a level always starts you an on a safe "island". The game can also be paused by hitting P. Thanks for your review.

review:
[b] Target Audience: [/b] [I]  Minesweeper Fans[/i]

[b] Summary: [/b]  
 
Honestly, when it comes down to it, you're paying for a visually upgraded version of Minesweeper, and  most likely, if you're reading this review at this point, you probably should grab the game because it's exactly that: an upgraded version of minesweeper. It's not blowing the doors off in any way, nice visuals do help the game but in the end, it's not breaking any walls in terms of gameplay. I do admit the right click feature on the numbers is nice in terms of revealing, that's a plus that I don't remember in the  original Windows 3.1 on the game. More features on the high score table would have been nice however, and overall, if you didn't like Minesweeper, there's nothing here to draw your attention, and you wanted a real advanced version of minesweeper, you'd be better looking at something like ManaCollect. But solid, and given the price tag, reasonable. 

[b]First Impressions and Gameplay:  https://youtu.be/_-aRnoC3_m0[/b] 

[u] Lists: [/u]
[b]Positives:[/b]
[list]
[*] It's Minesweeper.
[*] I may be wrong on this but I don't think I am: the right click feature added to click on numbers to automatically reveal spaces if the number quota has been filled is quite nice. 
[*] Do like the lives system, and a good last minute addition in the Classic Mode is good for nostalgia purposes.
[*] Visuals are strong, with good color choices and makes it feel great.
[*] Music, while not having a lot of variety, didn't actually get old surprisingly. Was catchy in a way.
[*] Custom mode is nice. 
[*] Developer was extremely responsive on info that came up during my play sessions, which is always a plus.
[/list]

[b]Negatives:[/b]
[list]
[*] It's Minesweeper.
[*] Needed a counter to count how many flags you've placed down so far, or you're just really counting mines for no reason. This is especially important later on in levels. 
[*] More leaderboard sorting options and detail would have been nice to see.
[*] I saw the word powerups, but it's basically lives. Would have been real interesting to add powerups like scanners or things of a different sort.
[/list]
